comments:
This course introduces the mathematics, algorithms, and practice of machine
learning. Covering the foundations of statistical machine learning, the course focuses on
probabilistic and statistical methods for prediction and clustering in high dimensions.
Other topics covered include graphical models, dimensionality reduction, neural
networks, and reinforcement learning. This course is aimed broadly at advanced
undergraduates and beginning graduate students. The software used in the course in
MATLAB.
Most students enjoyed the course very much even though it was quite tough.
Students generally indicated that “the subjects covered by the assignments and the
projects were very interesting” and the wiki layout for course lectures was wonderful.
While some students pointed out that the problems in the homework are sometimes
“slightly tangential to the focus” of the course and not closely related to exam questions,
the majority of the students thought this course stimulated their interest in machine
learning. One student even noted that this is “one of the most enjoyable core courses at
Penn.”
Professor Taskar and his TAs were highly praised by the students. Some students
reported that the professor and the TAs’ emphasis on “developing intuitions” despite “the
statistics-heavy nature” was “the best part about this course.” Many students greatly
complimented the TAs’ help, yet some wished that Professor Taskar could have “shown
up to office hours more often to answer questions and help students with their
homework.”
Students felt that the course was heavily math-oriented and thus was only
recommended for students who meet the prerequisites - Elementary Probability, Calculus,
Linear Algebra, and basic programming experience. The workload was high but the
assigned projects were mostly interesting.
